sentences.sentence: “My children,” said Aslan, fixing his eyes on( 注视 ) both of them, “you are to be the first King and Queen of Narnia.”
The Cabby( 马车夫 ) opened his mouth in astonishment( 惊奇 ), and his wife turned very red.
“You shall rule and name all these creatures, and do justice among them, and protect them from their enemies when enemies arise.
And enemies will arise, for there is an evil( 邪恶的 ) Witch( 女巫 ) in this world.”
The Cabby( 马车夫 ) swallowed hard two or three times and cleared his throat.

“Begging your pardon, sir,” he said, “and thanking you very much I’m sure (which my Missus does the same) but I’m not the sort of a chap( 男人 ) for a job like that. I never had much education, you see.”
“Well,” said Aslan, “can you use a spade( 铁锹 ) and a plow( 犁 ) and raise food out of the earth?”
“Yes, sir, I could do a bit of that sort of work: being brought up to it, like.”
“Can you rule these creatures kindly and fairly, remembering that they are not slaves like the dumb( 哑的 ) beasts of the world you were born in, but Talking Beasts and free subjects( 臣民 )?”
“I see that, sir,” replied the Cabby( 马车夫 ). “I’d try to do the square thing by them all.”
“And would you bring up your children and grandchildren to do the same?”
“It’d be up to me to try, sir. I’d do my best: wouldn’t we, Nellie?”
“And you wouldn’t have favorites either among your own children or among the other creatures or let any hold another under or use it hardly?”

“I never could abide( 容忍 ) such goings on, sir, and that’s the truth. I’d give them what for if I caught them at it,” said the Cabby( 马车夫 ). (All through this conversation his voice was growing slower and richer. More like the country voice he must have had as a boy and less like the sharp( 刺耳的 ), quick voice of a cockney( 伦敦东区腔 ).)
“And if enemies came against the land (for enemies will arise) and there was war, would you be the first in the charge and the last in the retreat( 撤退 )?”
“Well, sir,” said the Cabby( 马车夫 ) very slowly, “a chap( 男人 ) don’t exactly know till he’s been tried. I dare say I might turn out ever such a soft one.
Never did no fighting except with my fists. I’d try—that is, I hope I’d try—to do my bit.”
“Then,” said Aslan, “you will have done all that a King should do.
Your coronation( 加冕典礼 ) will be held presently. And you and your children and grandchildren shall be blessed, and some will be Kings of Narnia,
and others will be Kings of Archenland which lies yonder( 在那边 ) over the Southern Mountains.
And you, little Daughter” (here he turned to Polly) “are welcome.
Have you forgiven the Boy for the violence he did you in the Hall of Images in the desolate( 荒废的 ) palace of accursed( 被诅咒的 ) Charn?”
“Yes, Aslan, we’ve made it up,” said Polly.
“That is well,” said Aslan. “And now for the Boy himself.”
Digory kept his mouth very tight( 紧紧地 ) shut.
He had been growing more and more uncomfortable.
He hoped that, whatever happened, he wouldn’t blub( 哭泣 ) or do anything ridiculous( 可笑的 ).
“Son of Adam,” said Aslan. “Are you ready to undo( 弥补 ) the wrong that you have done to my sweet country of Narnia on the very day of its birth?”
“Well, I don’t see what I can do,” said Digory. “You see, the Queen ran away and—”
“I asked, are you ready?” said the Lion.
“Yes,” said Digory. He had had for a second some wild idea of saying “I’ll try to help you if you’ll promise to help my Mother,”
but he realized in time that the Lion was not at all the sort of person one could try to make bargains( 讨价还价 ) with.
But when he had said “Yes,” he thought of his Mother, and he thought of the great hopes he had had,
and how they were all dying away, and a lump came in his throat( 哽咽 ) and tears in his eyes, and he blurted( 脱口而出 ) out:
“But please, please—won’t you—can’t you give me something that will cure Mother?”
Up till then he had been looking at the Lion’s great feet and the huge claws on them; now, in his despair( 绝望 ), he looked up at its face.
What he saw surprised him as much as anything in his whole life.
For the tawny( 黄褐色的 ) face was bent down near his own and (wonder of wonders) great shining tears stood in the Lion’s eyes.
They were such big, bright tears compared with Digory’s own that for a moment he felt as if the Lion must really be sorrier about his Mother than he was himself.
“My son, my son,” said Aslan. “I know. Grief( 悲痛 ) is great. Only you and I in this land know that yet.
Let us be good to one another. But I have to think of hundreds of years in the life of Narnia.
The Witch( 女巫 ) whom you have brought into this world will come back to Narnia again.
But it need not be yet.
It is my wish to plant in Narnia a tree that she will not dare to approach, and that tree will protect Narnia from her for many years.
So this land shall have a long, bright morning before any clouds come over the sun. You must get me the seed from which that tree is to grow.”
“Yes, sir,” said Digory. He didn’t know how it was to be done but he felt quite sure now that he would be able to do it.
The Lion drew a deep breath, stooped( 低下 ) its head even lower and gave him a Lion’s kiss.
And at once Digory felt that new strength and courage had gone into him.
“Dear son,” said Aslan, “I will tell you what you must do. Turn and look to the West and tell me what do you see?”
“I see terribly big mountains, Aslan,” said Digory, “I see this river coming down cliffs( 悬崖 ) in a waterfall( 瀑布 ).
And beyond the cliff( 悬崖 ) there are high green hills with forests.
And beyond those there are higher ranges that look almost black.
And then, far away, there are big snowy mountains all heaped( 堆积 ) up together—like pictures of the Alps.
And behind those there’s nothing but the sky.”
“You see well,” said the Lion. “Now the land of Narnia ends where the waterfall( 瀑布 ) comes down,
and once you have reached the top of the cliffs( 悬崖 ) you will be out of Narnia and into the Western Wild.
You must journey through( 穿越 ) those mountains till you find a green valley with a blue lake in it, walled round by mountains of ice.
At the end of the lake there is a steep( 陡峭的 ), green hill.
On the top of that hill there is a garden.
In the center of that garden is a tree.
Pluck( 摘下 ) an apple from that tree and bring it back to me.”
“Yes, sir,” said Digory again. He hadn’t the least idea of how he was to climb the cliff( 悬崖 ) and find his way among all the mountains,
but he didn’t like to say that for fear it would sound like making excuses.
But he did say, “I hope, Aslan, you’re not in a hurry. I shan’t be able to get there and back very quickly.”
“Little son of Adam, you shall have help,” said Aslan.
He then turned to the Horse who had been standing quietly beside them all this time, swishing his tail to keep the flies off,
and listening with his head on one side as if the conversation were a little difficult to understand.
“My dear,” said Aslan to the Horse, “would you like to be a winged horse( 飞马 )?”
You should have seen how the Horse shook its mane( 鬃毛 ) and how its nostrils( 鼻孔 ) widened,
and the little tap it gave the ground with one back hoof( 蹄子 ). Clearly it would very much like to be a winged horse( 飞马 ). But it only said:
“If you wish, Aslan—if you really mean—I don’t know why it should be me—I’m not a very clever horse.”
“Be winged. Be the father of all flying horses,” roared( 大喊 ) Aslan in a voice that shook the ground. “Your name is Fledge.”
The horse shied, just as it might have shied in the old, miserable( 悲惨的 ) days when it pulled a hansom( 双轮有篷马车 ).
Then it roared( 大喊 ). It strained( 使劲 ) its neck back as if there were a fly biting its shoulders and it wanted to scratch( 抓 ) them.
And then, just as the beasts had burst out of the earth,
there burst out from the shoulders of Fledge wings that spread and grew, larger than eagles’, larger than swans’, larger than angels( 天使 )’ wings in church windows.
The feathers shone chestnut color( 栗色 ) and copper color( 古铜色 ).
He gave a great sweep with them and leaped( 跃向 ) into the air.
Twenty feet above Aslan and Digory he snorted( 喷鼻息 ), neighed( 嘶鸣 ), and curvetted( 腾跃 ).
Then, after circling once round them, he dropped to the earth, all four hoofs( 蹄子 ) together, looking awkward( 局促不安的 ) and surprised, but extremely pleased.
“Is it good, Fledge?” said Aslan.
“It is very good, Aslan,” said Fledge.

article_info.previous: 动物们正热火朝天地把Uncle Andrew种在地上，Digory请求Aslan赐予他可以治愈母亲的魔法果实，可是Aslan并没有给出明确的答复。为了把马车夫留在纳尼亚，Aslan答应了马车夫的请求，把他的妻子也带到了这儿。

article_info.share_words: The horse shied , just as it might have shied in the old, miserable days when it pulled a hansom. Then it roared. It strained its neck back as if there were a fly biting its shoulders and it wanted to scratch them.

question.cn: 谁被狮子任命为纳尼亚的国王和王后？
question.en: Who were appointed as the King and Queen of Narnia by the Lion?

analysis: 文中提到：“‘My children. . . you are to be the first King and Queen of Narnia.’  The Cabby opened his mouth in astonishment, and his wife turned very red.”由此可知，Aslan任命马车夫和他的妻子分别为纳尼亚的第一任国王和王后，因此选A。

question.cn: 当狮子任命马车夫为国王时，他是什么反应？
question.en: How did the Cabby feel when the Lion appointed him as King?

analysis: 文中提到：“The Cabby opened his mouth in astonishment, and his wife turned very red.”由此可知，当Aslan宣布马车夫为纳尼亚国王时，马车夫十分惊讶地张大了嘴，因此选B。

question.cn: 在本章的末尾，加冕典礼举行了吗？
question.en: At the end of this chapter, was the coronation held?

analysis: 虽然本章提到：“You coronation will be held presently.”但是到末尾结束，加冕典礼也没有举行，因此选B。

question.cn: 当Digory抬头看狮子的脸时，什么让Digory十分吃惊？
question.en: What surprised Digory most when Digory looked up at Lion's face?

analysis: 文中提到：“What he saw surprised him as much as anything in his whole world. For his tawny face was bent down near his own and great shining tears stood in Lion’s eyes.”由此可知当Digory抬头时，令他吃惊的事是Aslan也哭泣了，因此选B。.

question.en: What was Digory’s task given by the Lion?

analysis: 文中提到：“In the center of that garden is a tree. Pluck an apple from that tree and bring it back to me.”由此可知Aslan赋予Digroy的重任是摘苹果，因此选A。
